text: this is matt Wald at the New York Times
at the recent briefing by the National
Transportation Safety Board on the
progress of the investigation into the
US air flight that came down in the
Hudson River on Thursday afternoon the
board has made some progress but there's
a whole lot the investigators don't know
yet the effort has been affected by the
strong current which is really limited
the amount of dive time that we've had
that the divers can only be in the water
for a certain amount of time so they are
working tonight really I think until
midnight to rig that aircraft so it can
be hauled out tomorrow morning in
addition this time they know where the
black boxes are the flight data recorder
the cockpit voice recorder but they
can't get them because the currents are
too strong they're hoping to get the
plane out of the water tomorrow and then
get the boxes the investigators
preferred data they also like interviews
but they haven't interviewed the cockpit
crew yet they hope to do that tomorrow
also they will be listing the cockpit
voice recorder which captures not only
voices but also sounds in the cockpit
including bird impacts if there were any
they also at this point are missing both
engines the engines probably came off
when the
hit the water we could see that the left
engine was not attached as the plane was
pulled into the into its current
location under the divers were able to
tell us that the right engine is also no
longer there so we've got the new york
police department working with the Corps
of Engineers and using side-scan sonar
and they are out there now trying to
locate the engines and the engines will
show physical evidence of bird strike if
that's what happened kitty Higgins the
board member in charge here says that
they can get DNA out of the engines that
even find out what kind of bird it was
but at the moment they're not committing
themselves to anything even that the
cause was a bird strike
